On 24 May 2010 08:45, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
>
> Colin, yes, the idea of a powerful representation that can easily capture the most important
> operations (such as comparison or multiplication) is always lurking in the background. Yet
> trade-offs always seem to emerge when we try to bestow such capabilities explicitly. For
> example, if we added multiplication, it may theoretically allow certain key computations to be
> represented easily, yet it also gives evolution a new power to more easily destroy what it has
> built through trivial mutations (because multiplication is more powerful than summation).

Point acknowledged.

> I am sure that CPPNs as a representational formalism can be improved, yet the presence of
> these nagging trade-offs makes me think that the idea of a super-powerful representation is a
> false ideal. It seems to me at this point that evolution in nature succeeds despite the limited
> nature of its representation rather than because DNA is somehow near perfect.

I accept you chain of reasoning but I don't accept the
foundation/axiom that natural neurons don't perform multiplication and
comparison (and possibly quite a few other operations) at the neuronal
level. Christoph Koch's work is a good starting point to learn more
about what functionality is present in individual neurons (see
Biophysics of Computation, section 21.1.1 Many Ways to Multiply). I'll
pick one example which I think is the most significant -
multiplication via addition and logarithms:

    log(x*y) = log(x) + log(y)

Thus:

   x*y = e^(log(x) + log(y))

Logarithms occur naturally by decay of some neurotransmitter
concentration over the length of an axon or dendrite.

Another compelling example is the non-linear interation of
neurotransmitters in dendrites. Say we have incoming signals x and y
which connect at sites X and Y on the dendritic tree. Those two sites
produce two different neurotransmitters when excited and the resulting
excitation of the neuron is the *product* of the two neurotransmitter
concentrations. Why? Because one neurotransmitter acts chemically and
electrically in improving the flow of the other (or more specifically,
improving the flow of ions produced by the stimulating effects of the
other). This setup is much like a transistor, and one use of
transitors is of course amplification AKA multiplication.


> Of course, these thoughts don't contradict anything you said. The length input trick also
> shows that to some extent we can provide dramatic bias through a priori knowledge, which is
> a good thing (e.g. if it means skipping 10,000 years of evolution).

My concern is that this was a simple test case where simple euclidean
distance applied in an obvious way. Ideally I want HyperNEAT to learn
what distance metrics apply to the problem rather than me suppling
them precomputed.

I think there's a strong case for taking a fresh look at what
computations we perform at the neuronal level and whether traditional
sigmoid based ANNs are deficient in some significant ways. I hope you
can see where I'm coming from here.

Colin.
